Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigating Core Issues in Learning Progressions Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project conducts two parallel studies on learning progressions (LPs). LPs embody a developmental approach to learning as they describe the paths that students might take as students develop progressively more sophisticated ways of reasoning about scientific concepts and practices in a domain. Therefore, this project investigates the theoretical validity of LPs based on the outcomes of earlier studies to better understand what can be learned about how student knowledge develops in genetics.

Two research questions will guide the studies.

1. To what extent does the notion of well-defined and highly constrained learning paths reflect the actual development of students? learning in a domain?

2. In what ways do the learning of scientific content and scientific practices interact in science LPs? That is, what are the affordances and constraints that particular content learning paths pose on the learning of scientific practices?

The first study addresses both research questions by comparing two genetics LPs through a dual implementation of instructional units that also include a focus on modeling practice. This comparison provides additional evidence regarding the type and relative strength of the conceptual constraints and affordances that drive the development of student knowledge in genetics. The participating mid-sized suburban district uses a physics-first curriculum where biology is taught last in the science sequence at the11th grade. Participants include four high school teachers and their students. The project impacts about 70 students per teacher or 560 over two implementations.

The second study addresses only the first research question and employs a cross-sectional design to examine the development of the genetics knowledge of students from late elementary to college. This cross-sectional design provides additional evidence about the conceptual constraints and affordances in the development of genetics knowledge given a much broader sample from varying instructional contexts. Students at 5th, 7th, 9th, and 11th grades from public and private schools as well as undergraduates and graduates from Rutgers, Montclair, and Princeton participate in the second study. The sample includes about 200 students from each group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learning progressions are hypothetical models of how learners develop their understandings of central ideas in science over time. These models describe progressively more sophisticated ways of reasoning about science ideas, and we assume that learners growth in sophistication is dependent upon carefully designed instruction. While it may seem obvious that instruction clearly impacts learning, we still do not know how many possible learning progression there are for any particular central idea. That is, could it be that each instructional sequence results in a different progression or do students tend to master ideas in a particular order regardless of the order in which these ideas were taught? The aim of the Investigating Core Issues in Learning Progressions Research (I2LeaPs) Project is to investigate the extent to which differences in instruction impact the progression of students’ understanding of key science ideas. We explored this question in the context of a genetics learning progression and by developing two alternative instructional sequences that were implemented by high school biology teachers and their 11th grade students. Our conjecture was that if one of the instructional sequences was better aligned to the “natural” progression of students learning then students receiving that sequence would learn more than their peers who were learning with a different sequence. We found that instructional sequence did not make a statistically significant difference in learning gains, however, there was a clear (yet non-significant) trend favoring one of the sequences suggesting that there may be a preferable sequence. This finding implies, albeit weakly, that some progression models may be better aligned with the developmental constraints and affordances involved learning particular ideas in science.

 Intellectual Merit

Learning progressions hold much promise in helping to make curriculum and instruction more coherent over schooling and achieving better learning outcomes for students. At their core is the assumption that there is a small and limited number of effective ways in which students can build knowledge and develop more sophisticated understandings. Uncovering these few of paths can inform more effective instruction. If this is not the case, as some researchers argue, and there are many possible learning paths that depend on individual learners’ prior knowledge and specific context, then the potential contribution of progressions is questionable. Understanding the extent to which progressions are invariant across learners is a central issue in the field. This project has began tackling this issue using methodologies that can shed light on the questions of how many paths there are and how sensitive they are to variations in instructional sequences.

 Broader Impact

As part of this project we developed two instructional units in genetics (comprising a total of 8-10 weeks of instruction) as well as assessments to measure student learning. Insights and sample materials from this project have been disseminated to researchers and teachers through various venues including National Science Teacher Association professional development webinars and workshops. Through this project we have trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students in research work. Lastly, instructional materials and student artifacts are being used in teacher preparation courses taught by the PI.
